Resolved Question Show me another » Is it really cheaper to eat fast food than to cook for yourself? I'm going to set my question in the context of a group of 4. I have not been to a fast food place in over 10 years, and I am still a college student. Therefore my income isn't very high, but I still manage to spend maybe $60 a month on vegetables, cereals, milk, etc etc. I love to cook, so I always buy raw ingredients, and it doesn't bother me that I have to prepare it.
People always say that part of America's obesity problem is because fast food is so available and so cheap. IS eating at a fast food place, not even daily, but let's say 2 or 3 times a week, really cheaper than going to a grocery store? Please think before you answer. Don't just consider the fact that it's about $5 to get a burger or whatever, and at a supermarket, that's about 2lbs of tomatoes. Please consider that when you're shopping at a supermarket, you're purchasing ingredients that make more than just the singular serving one might be purchasing from a fast food place. 5 years ago Report Abuse
Additional Details Originally I had thought it was around $60, but I took a look at my receipts for a more accurate count and it ranges from about $120-$190 per month. 5 years ago by Abby Member since: April 02, 2007 Total points: 465 (Level 2) Add Contact Block

Let me first start off saying, there is no way you spend only 60 dollars a month on food, especially if you are eating as healthy as you do. The more healthy you eat the more money it cost. Right now, food is more expensive than it has ever been in history (on a cost adjusted basis). It is definitely cheaper to eat fast food now then going grocery shopping.
Crazy isn't it, that food has become so expensive.
Fact about fast food.... Unhealthy food is cheaper because our government's policies support its production.
We're spending nearly $30 billion a year to subsidize corn and soy production.
Where do those foods go?
Into our food supply as high-fructose corn syrup and hydrogenated soybean oil (trans fats), that's where!
Since the 1970s -- when our agricultural policies where changed to support corn and soy farmers -- we're consuming, on average, an extra 500 calories (mostly in the form of cheap, artificial high-fructose corn syrup) per person.
Corn and soy are also used to feed cattle for the production of meat and dairy. In fact, 70 percent of the wheat, corn, and soy farmed in this country is used to feed animals used for our food.
The world's cattle alone consume a quantity of food equal to the caloric needs of 8.7 billion people -- more than the entire human population on Earth!
So, when our government helps pay for these foods -- well, of course they're cheaper!
That explains the low price tag. But what about the OTHER costs to you? Bad foods are bad for your health...
